input:
**User**: 
Write a 300+ word summary of the wikipedia page "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_III,_Count_of_Tripoli". Do not use any commas and highlight at least 3 sections that has titles in markdown format, for example *highlighted section part 1*, *highlighted section part 2*, *highlighted section part 3*.

score.extracted_prediction:
*Raymond III's Early Life*  
Raymond III Count of Tripoli was born around 1120. He was the son of Raymond II Count of Tripoli and Alice of Jerusalem. He grew up in the court of Tripoli and received a noble education. His early years were marked by the influence of the Crusader states and the Christian kingdoms of the Levant.  

*Reign and Crusader Politics*  
He became Count of Tripoli in 1152 after the death of his father. His reign lasted until 1187. He faced internal disputes among the nobility and external threats from the Seljuk Turks. He maintained alliances with the Kingdom of Jerusalem and the Principality of Antioch. He was a patron of the Hospitallers and the Templars and supported their military and charitable activities.  

*Battle of Hattin and Capture*  
In 1187 he joined the Crusader army at the Battle of Hattin. He fought bravely but the Crusaders were defeated by Saladin. He was captured and held as a prisoner. A ransom was paid for his release and he returned to Tripoli. He died later that year after his return.  

*Family and Legacy*  
He married a noblewoman and had several children. His son Raymond IV succeeded him as Count of Tripoli. His daughter Alice married Bohemond III of Antioch. He is remembered for his defense of Tripoli and his patronage of the arts and architecture. His legacy lives on in the citadel of Tripoli and in the chronicles of the Crusader states.  

His reign exemplified the resilience of the Crusader nobility in the face of shifting political landscapes. The citadel he helped fortify remains a testament to his strategic foresight. Scholars continue to study his life to understand the complexities of medieval Levantine politics.
